title: Ghana: Ghana Armed Forces Receive Infrastructural Facelift
text:
Ghana Armed Forces Receive Infrastructural Facelift Tagged: Zimbabwe: Govt Engages Contractor On Beitbridge press release 
Expansion and upgrading of infrastructure for the Ghana Armed Forces (GAF) continues to receive serious attention, various Units having seen facelifts with the successful completion of several projects to improve on their office and residential accommodation challenges. 
Some of the projects include a new Academy Hall, a 16-unit (two-bedroom) officers' quarters which have been completed and handed over while the construction of and a new Officers' Mess for the Military Academy and Training School (MATS) is 40 per cent complete. 
In addition, the Army Mess Project-- a 3-phase project which include the construction of an ultra-modern Officers' Mess Complex, an apartment for 96 single-officers and a 48 3-bedroom married quarters in Burma Camp-- is also being undertaken under a Public-Private Partnership arrangement. Related Topics Zimbabwe: Govt Engages Contractor On Beitbridge 
A similar project is also being undertaken on Drake Avenue in the Airport Residential Area. 
Dr Benjamin Kunbour, Minister for Defence, made these known when he addressed the media at the Meet-The-Press series in Accra, yesterday. 
Dr Kunbuor disclosed that work was progressing steadily under the Housing for Security Services Scheme Project for the construction of 368 Housing Units at Paradise Beach Tema for the Ghana Navy, adding that the Navy was the only arm of GAF without a dedicated barracks. 
He said the Paradise Beach Project, sponsored by the government through the Ministry of Water Resources, Works and Housing, would help mitigate the acute accommodation problem facing the Navy. 
Dr Kumbour also announced that the construction of a new 500-bed Military Hospital at Afari, near Kumasi, in the Ashanti region, which is expected to be completed in 42 months after signing the contract in March 2014, was also progressing speedily. 
The new Military Hospital in Kumasi, when completed will be the 2nd biggest Military Hospital after the 37 Military Hospital in Ghana and is expected to serve the military and civilian communities in the Ashanti, Brong Ahafo, Northern, Upper East and Upper West Regions. 
Other on-going infrastructural development projects, Dr Kunbour said, included the renovation, expansion and redesigning of the Ghana Air Force (GAF) Headquarters into a four-storey office building; renovation of the Officers' Mess at the Air Force Base in Takoradi, construction of a 54-unit single room self-contained accommodation for young airmen and airwomen in Accra and Takoradi; construction of offices for Retired Commissioned Air Force Officers Association in Accra; construction of a Container village at the Air Force Base in Accra for the storage and maintenance of specialists and critical spares; and the construction of Junior Ranks Mess at the Air Force Base in Takoradi. 
Completed projects for GAF, he said, were Flats for young officers at Air Force Bases in Accra and Takoradi; Ultra-modern 'matambo' at Air Force Officers' Mess in Accra; a modern Guardroom, Armoury and Main Gate at Air Force Base in Accra; production Centre at Air Force Base in Takoradi; and Guard Points at Air Force Bases in Accra and Takoradi. 
On Housing projects, Dr Kunbour said some of the PTI and Social Security and National Insurance (SSNIT) Housing Projects and the Affordable Housing Units for the Military at Borteyman had been completed while the Military Training Camps in Daboya and Bundase had also seen major facelifts. 
He disclosed that under the German Equipment Aid Programme, GAF had benefited from 1.5 million Euros worth of equipment from Germany as that country's contribution towards the establishment of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) Standby Force. 
He said the package, which included nine Man Trucks, two Speedboats, vehicle maintenance equipment and a number of Mercedes Benz Trucks, was handed over by the German Armed Forces Technical Advisory Group (GAFTAG) in January, this year. 
Source: ISD (G.D. Zaney)
